posts.name: Randomuser1234567@@@
posts.cooked: Did they fix it? thank you

Let543:

Did they fix it? thank you

I think this is misconception. There are:
a) messages (texting & pictures).
b) calls (voice & video).

Disappearing messages are for messages, that is option a). Calls are separately dealed.

What I think about misconception is that this is not a bug to be fixed. It is a feature request to make call metadata disappearing to behave like text messsages data disappearing. We just must wait for new feature to be implemented. Probably is not on the top of the list of new features in my humble opinion.

Don’t get me wrong, I would like to have this feature too.

link_counts.title: Add Call details

posts.name: Randomuser1234567@@@
posts.cooked: I know but the metadata is dangerous for our privacy. Is it important as well as any other privacy feature.

@Let543, can you explain what is the use case for disappearing calls metadata? I see it like this, multiple activists gather together on protest and they are coordinating protest using the phone and Signal program. Sending text message as disappear like after 5 seconds. This is fine and message gets delete from receiver and sender phones. But establish a call and it leaves the traces of metadata. Users have to manually delete the metadata calls. In protest “panic” this is not simple to do and if one forgets to delete and there are left traces that police can get the calls metadata if phone is confiscated.

The only problem I see is this new feature is probably not on top of the list of Signal developers. Why? This effects only few of the Signal users. We can see only few of the post of this forum thread. If this feature would be something a lot of people could not leave without, this thread would have huge number of posts.

What Signal currently needs is much bigger user base and to get this it is required to add new features that most of the users need.

Don’t get me wrong, I would also like to have this feature, +1 for me, but we need to be realistic not to expect to be on top of the new features list.

posts.name: Randomuser1234567@@@
posts.cooked:
The Calls metadata or the name group changing metadata are laks of our privacy. If I set disappearing messages I want that everything will disappear after the time I have set.

It is simple!

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
IMPORTANT:
imo, there is BIG BUG with disappearing messages, since this does not cover the call history (logs).

Please see also:

Catalan Referendum coordinated with signal General Discussion
I don’t know if here people are aware that signal was key to the organizing of the Catalan referendum defying a state like Spain who interdicted even the Catalan goverment accounts. For the coordination signal was used. Part of the conversations were cracked by the old method of seizing the mobile phone of one of the partners, and one of the groups didn’t had the disappearing messages feature enabled. Also, another point, that could serve as lesson. Even that you have disappearing messages ther…

btw, we should (re)file a new GitHub issue for this

EDIT: done

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

disappearing messages does not cover call logs

opened 08:39AM - 11 Apr 18 UTC
closed 11:34PM - 12 Apr 18 UTC
ghost

- [x] I have searched open and closed issues for duplicates - [x] I am submitti…ng a bug report for existing functionality that does not work as intended - [x] I have read https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports - [x] This isn't a feature request or a discussion topic ---------------------------------------- legacy issue: #6879 related: #5628 ### Bug description from legacy issue: The awesome "disappearing messages" feature does not cover call notifications (`MessageRecord_called_s` and `MessageRecord_s_called_you`). IMHO they should disappear the same way other messages do. For one, these kinds of metadata records can be sensitive information, too. And from a user perspective, "messages" should cover all message types. Please see also: https://community.signalusers.org/t/catalan-referendum-coordinated-with-signal/1609 and/or [La Guardia Civil revienta el chat secreto en Signal de los 'arquitectos' digitales del 1-O](https://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/2017-11-22/independencia-cataluna-guardia-civil-revienta-chat-secreto-signal-arquitectos-digitales-referendum_1481632/) ### Steps to reproduce - set "disappearing messages" to any value - make or receive call(s) - wait until time for disappearing messages has passed **Actual result:** call notification does not disappear **Expected result:** call notification disappears ### Screenshots see video: https://vod.elconfidencial.com/834/d17/834d17b54baa9876bc8fc0700ef40508_26.mp4 ### Device info **Device:** any **Android version:** any **Signal version:** Signal v4.17.5 ### Link to debug log imo, not relevant

posts.cooked:
Automatic expiration of messages

there is BIG BUG with disappearing messages, since this does not cover the call history

It is debatable if this is a bug or feature request. Signal was made by joining two applications TextSecure (for texting) and RedPhone (calls). From historical point of view there are two separate services combined into one single application, to mask there is only one service (text+call), to be more user friendly. Texting and calls are using two different protocols for transferring data. And probably require two different implementations for “disappearing messages”. Another point, with texting is: text is actual data, when using calls, message that call was established is metadata (= data about data, data itself are calls). Texting today has support for disappearing messages, but calls do not. It can be seen as feature only implemented for texting, but not for calls. That is one possible interpretation. If this is correct explanation, then disappearing metadata calls is not a bug and does not belong to Github bug tracker.

On the other hand, from end-user perspective, specially activists, Signal can be seen as one united service (text+call) and with disappearing feature actually see as delete all traces of communication.

Don’t get me wrong, I actually would also like to see disappearing messages to also include deleting calls metadata. My point is just we can’t really say this is a bug, or even to use stronger words BIG BUG, which may indeed be feature request.

link_counts.title: Automatic expiration of messages

posts.cooked:
Hello, thanks for the clarification.

From the point of view of someone on the frontlines, who is using the “disappearing messages”, it makes a more sense that the call logs also disappears. I was asked about this by activists before and found it hard to explain the logic behind it (as you pointed out).

I hope you consider including the disappearing feature to cover the call logs. (and any other logs that are not inlcuded yet), at least as an option to fulfil the need for those who really need it. Especially if other users/developers have a different opinion on this.

Thanks!

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
shellSignal:

Another point, with texting is: text is actual data, when using calls, message that call was established is metadata (= data about data, data itself are calls).

hmmm, well, even only text messages have metadata (timestamp, status (received, read,…)) and those are covered from disappearing messages. Moxie wrote today: This is the intended functionality. It's possible that we should revisit what is intended,.... imo, then the call logs/notifications should NOT be merged with the text messages. Probbably, moving call logs/notifications to a new tab or whatever will help to not misinterpret the functionality of disappearing messages.

Hello!

I have no idea, whether this should be a bug report, or a feature request. And to be honest, I think that question is not really important. Since disappearing messages are already implemented, it should be really a bagatelle to expand the disappearing messages to the call history. 3-4 hours or so…

That is something I observe for some time now, that obvious things, which are annoying for some (many?) users, and which are not so complicated to fix (like this here, or Landscape Rotation), take forever, or are not settled at all, and other things, which are much more complicated and difficult to implement, are given a higher priority.

I think, the Signal team should think about their priorization procedure…

Kathy

kathy:

be a bug report, or a feature request. And to be honest, I think that question is not really important.

It is important, because bugs have absolute priority. New feature request is in the the list of most wanted features. Because moxie closed the issue, we can assume moxie things it is feature request not a bug.

kathy:

which are annoying for some (many?) users, and which are not so complicated to fix

It is annoying for many, but there are other features that may be more important (more users would like to have). I don’t know how complicated is to fix/implement this bug/feature, but someone should really know the source code well before saying that it is easy. It may appear trivially to fix, but it may not be. I don’t know.

kathy:

I think, the Signal team should think about their priorization procedure…

I am sure there is nothing wrong with prioritization procedure. There is just a lot on the list of new features and they need to make smart decisions on how to spend there resources.

We need to be patient. Be constructive on forum, be beta testers, etc. Reporting bug reports instead opening feature request on forum will not help improve, it just takes away precious developers time that could be used on bug fixing and implementing features from the feature prioritization list. We need to be more patient and provide good argument why something is important to implement and encourage others to be included in conversation. More users want a feature, better the chances to be implemented soon.

kathy:

it should be really a bagatelle to expand the disappearing messages to the call history. 3-4 hours or so…

OK then! Please submit your PR by, say, Monday - there’s a full weekend ahead of you, more than enough. Have fun!

AlfonsoMuskedunder:

OK then! Please submit your PR by, say, Monday - there’s a full weekend ahead of you, more than enough. Have fun!

Hello!

Thanks, I have a job and get paid for it. And Signal has now enough money to employ people, who currently look for a job.

Kathy

shellSignal:

It is important, because bugs have absolute priority. New feature request is in the the list of most wanted features. Because moxie closed the issue, we can assume moxie things it is feature request not a bug.

Hello!

Well, bugs should not always have priority. If you have every worked in a software project, you know, that it can really become a problem, if you have too many bugs, and are 100% busy with cleaning up, the software will make no progress. There must be some balance: always a part of the work for bugs and a part for new feature, which are essential. Of course it does not help much, if people suggest pink color schemes

shellSignal:

I am sure there is nothing wrong with prioritization procedure. There is just a lot on the list of new features and they need to make smart decisions on how to spend there resources.

We need to be patient. Be constructive on forum, be beta testers, etc

I disagree with you. I believe, that the signal team just needs 1 or 2 additional people, who are 20+ years in Software business, and who have really experience with prioritization. I think all people, who requested features here, have alot of patience, if they open a feature request, and nothing happens for 3 years.

I am even not sure anymore, whether it makes any sense to report new bugs, or suggest new things. We all would have to completey shut up for 3 years, so that the team can catch up with the current feature request and bug reporting status.

Kathy

What if call logs are displayed like a message (bubble). That way call logs would self-destruct just like normal text messages.

quick mockup

callMessageBubble.png1080×1920 58.3 KB

@mikaseh, what would happen if Sam send: “Called Sam Poll”, I know very unlikely, but message would be undistinguished from call info. I actually like to have a distinction, grey colour, for call metadata.

kathy:

Of course it does not help much, if people suggest pink color schemes

I would better see pink theme then disappearing calls info. Disappearing calls are actually RELLY needed only by few, like activists, journalists and similar. But pink theme would attract many girls and girly by heart. ;)
